NAME: Fe(2+)
UNIPROT ANNOTATION: The purified enzyme contains a mixture of Fe(2+) and Zn(2+) bound in the active site, and a single equivalent of metal is required for full catalytic activity. After removal of the metal, the reconstitution of the enzyme with Fe(2+) gives the highest activity, followed by Mn(2+), and, to a much lesser extent, Co(2+) and Zn(2+). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21545144, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8226944};

NAME: Mg(2+)
UNIPROT ANNOTATION: Requires a divalent cation, most likely magnesium in vivo, as an electrophilic catalyst to aid phosphoryl group transfer. NAME: Zn(2+)
UNIPROT ANNOTATION: Can use either Fe(2+) or Zn(2+). The metal cofactor can switch between Fe(2+) and Zn(2+) in response to metal availability. Metal switching may be important for regulating the LpxC activity upon changes in environmental conditions. Has a significantly higher affinity for Zn(2+), but exhibits higher activity with Fe(2+) (PubMed:20136146, PubMed:20709752). Can also use Co(2+), Ni(2+) and, to a lesser extent, Mn(2+) (PubMed:10026271). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10026271, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20136146, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20709752};

NAME: Fe(2+)
UNIPROT ANNOTATION: Can use either Fe(2+) or Zn(2+). The metal cofactor can switch between Fe(2+) and Zn(2+) in response to metal availability. Metal switching may be important for regulating the LpxC activity upon changes in environmental conditions. Has a significantly higher affinity for Zn(2+), but exhibits higher activity with Fe(2+) (PubMed:20136146, PubMed:20709752). Can also use Co(2+), Ni(2+) and, to a lesser extent, Mn(2+) (PubMed:10026271). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10026271, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20136146, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20709752};
